markdown: period, no significant increase in tooth decay occurred when com- pared to those eating a low-sugar diet. On the other hand, those who ate sticky carbohydrates between meals developed more cavities. Soft Drinks and Tooth Decay Because of their liquid form and the short time they remain in the mouth, soft drinks which con- tain sugar do not have as signifi- cant an impact on tooth decay as sugar-containing sticky foods. One question frequently raised about soft drinks is whether they cause teeth to erode or dissolve. This concern arises because many people have seen demonstrations in which a tooth erodes or disappears after being immersed in a soft drink for several days. Unfortunately, these experiments do not demonstrate what actually happens in the mouth and only serve to unneces- sarily alarm people. When a tooth is placed in any acidic solution, such as a soft drink or a fruit juice, and is left there for a number of days, erosion will take place. But this is not what happens in the mouth. In the mouth, teeth are exposed to a soft drink for only a very short period of time and are constantly bathed in a protective wash of saliva, which acts to decrease the effect of the acid. In conclusion, you can reduce your chances of develop- ing tooth decay by following a few simple guidelines. * Visit your dentist regularly, use fluoride routinely and keep your teeth clean by frequent brushing and flossing. * Decrease the number of times that sticky carbohydrates are eaten. The more frequently these foods are eaten, the more times teeth are subject to condi- tions promoting decay. * Try to limit the consumption of sticky carbohydrates to meal- times when other foods and liquids will help remove them from the mouth. * Rinse your mouth with water after eating if you are unable to brush your teeth. * Avoid putting infants and young children to bed with a bottle containing sweetened liquids, including fruit juice, milk or formula. The normally rapid clearance time of liquids through the mouth does not occur in this situation, and the teeth are exposed to the liquid for an extended period of time. * Choose a variety of foods from all the basic food groups. Eating many different kinds of foods in moderate amounts is the key to a balanced diet and promotes general good health. The Coca-Cola Company supports the need for further dental research and educational programs to clarify the facts about tooth decay and good dental health. For more technical informa- tion on soft drinks and dental health or other ingredient-related questions, please write or call: Consumer Information Center Coca-Cola USA P.O. Journal of Dental Research 1975; 59:2194. 3. Bibby, B.G. The cariogenicity of snack foods and confections. Journal of the American Dental Association 1975 Jan.; 90(1): 121-132. 4. Carlos, J.P. The prevention of dental caries: ten years later. Journal of the American Dental Association 1982; 104:193. 5. Edgar, W.M., et al. Acid production in plaques after eating snacks: modifying factors in foods. Journal of the American Dental Association 1975 Feb.; 90(2): 418-425. 6. Glass, R.L. The first international conference on the declining prevalence of dental caries. Journal of Dental Research 1982; 61:1301. 7. Gustafson, B.E., et al. Vipeholm dental caries study. Acta Odontologica Scandinavia 1954; 11:232. Source: https://www.industrydocuments.ucsf.edu/docs/mtyj0226
